questions.text: Culture media that is helpful in differentiating lactose fermenters vs non-lactose fermenters
questions.solution:
Topic: Culture media

SubTopic: Differential media

There are many culture media used in lab. All have their specific use. Some are used as enriched media, some used as enrichment media. Some are differential media.

  • MacConkey is differential media. It differentiates lactose fermenting and non lactose fermenting bacteria.
  • Mechanism of MacConkey’s Agar-Lactose fermenting bacteria will give pink colonies and non lactose fermenting bacteria will give pale colonies.
  • Reason behind this mechanism is when lactose is fermented by bacteria end product is acid, so Ph of medium will change and because of change of Ph indicator present in macconckey agar will give pink colour.
  • Lactose fermenting bacteria are E coli, Klebsiella, etc
  • Non lactose fermenting bacteria are salmonella, shigella spp, pseudomonas

Reference: Ananthnarayan and paniker’s textbook of Microbiology 12th edition, page number:25

questions.text: Pasteurization test done for milk is done by all except
questions.solution:
Topic: General microbiology

SubTopic: Sterilization

  • To test pasteurization one common test is done.
  • Alkaline phosphatase test, it is an indicator of adequate pasteurization of milk and cream.

A proprietary fluorometric technique is a sensitive and quantitative method for the determination of alkaline phosphatase activity in milk products.

  • Other tests are methylene blue reduction test and Standard plate count.
  • Coliform count method is used for water testing.

Reference: Ananthnarayan and paniker’s textbook of Microbiology 12th edition ,page number 701

questions.text: Work of vaccine for SARS COV-2 is done in which of the following levels?
questions.solution:
Topic: General microbiology

SubTopic: BiosafetyIn microbiology there are four BSL (Biosafety levels)-BSL1, BSL 2, BSL 3 and BSL 4

Depending on severity of infecting organism, different BSL is used.

  • COVID was easily transmitted among peoples, and it produced pandemic. So BSL 3 is required for work done related to COVID. Vaccine production for COVID 19 is to be done in BSL 3.
  • EBOLA, CCHF requires BSL 4.
  • E coli causing diarrhea, food poisoning are to be processed in BSL 1
  • Shigella, salmonella etc to be processed in BSL 2.

Reference: Ananthnarayan and paniker’s textbook of Microbiology 12th edition page number:123

questions.text: All of the following are measures used against COVID19 EXCEPT
questions.solution:
COVID 19 was highly infectious, it was spreading from one person to other by inhalation, tough, coughing, through inanimate objects.

  • So 70 % ethanol was used as hand sterilizer.
  • Face masks were used to prevent aerosol transmission.
  • Hand washing with soap was also helpful because contaminated hands can transmit the infection.
  • 1% gluteraldehyde has NO ROLE. It is high level disinfectant. It is used to sterilize the bronchoscopes, laparoscopes.

Topic: General microbiology

SubTopic: Infection control

Reference: Essential of medical microbiology, by Apurba sastry and sandhya bhat, 4th edition, page number:51

questions.text: Needle prick in an HCW, patient HBV reactive, anti-HBs >90mIU for HBV prophylaxis. What is to be done?
questions.solution:
Topic: General microbiology

SubTopic: Infection control

An occupational exposure is defined as

Percutaneous injury – Needle stick injury or other sharp injury

Splash injury – contact with mucus membrane (Eye or mouth)

Contact with non intact skin (abraded skin or afflicted with dermatitis)

Contact with the intact skin when the duration is prolonged (several minutes or more)

HIV, HCV, HBV can be transmitted by needle stick injury.

When needle stick injury occur, person must report to head of that unit and then to infection control nurse or officer.

Basic tests to be performed for patient as well as health care worker,

If his Anti HBS title is more than 90 MlU then nothing is to be given as per standard guidelines.

If the titre are less then anti serum and vaccines both need to be started.

Reference: Essential of medical microbiology, by Apurba sastry and sandhya bhat, 4th edition, page number:237

questions.text: The cells that participate in inflammation known as Macrophages are known by what name in the liver
questions.solution:
Topic: Immunology

SubTopic: Cells of immune system

Macrophage in different organs has different names.

In liver – kupffer cells

Blood – Monocyte

Lung – Alveolar macrophage

Bone – Osteoclast

Kidney – Mesangial cell

Brain – Microglia

Reference: Ananthnarayan and paniker’s textbook of Microbiology 12th edition, page number 134

questions.text: Rheumatoid arthritis happens due to:
questions.solution:
Topic: Immunology

SubTopic: Autoimmune disease

There are many autoimmune disorders.Autoimmunity is reactivity of body towards self antigen, in this immune system starts to consider the host cell as foreign antigen and mounts an immune response against it. Examples of Autoimmune disease

Organ specific’

Hashimoto thyroiditis

Good pasture syndrome

IDDM

Auto immune hepatitis

Auto immune hemolytic anemia

Pernicious anemia

Myasthenia gravis

Autoimmune thromobocytopenia

Multiple sclerosis

Grave’s disease

Systemic autoimmune disorder

SLE

RA

PAN

Reiter syndrome

Sjogren syndrome

Wegner’s granulomatosis

Systemic sclerosis

Inflammatory myopathies

Reference: Ananthnarayan and paniker’s textbook of Microbiology 12th edition, page number:178

questions.text: A patient develops runny nose, wheezing several times a year. These features are due to degranulation of which of the following cells?
questions.solution:
This is a case of Type I hypersensitivity. Mechanism of this hypersensitivity is that in sensitization phase and late phase response. In this hyper sensitivity IgE and Mast cells are important. After first exposure of antigen the helper T cells work as antigen presentation and B cell will form IgE. These antibodies will bind to mast cells and Basophils.

When second time the same antigen comes, Mast cell degranulation occurs and patient will have smooth muscle spasm, increase mucus secretion from epithelial cells, vasodilation, increase vascular permeability, recruitement of inflammatory cells.

Topic: Immunology

SubTopic: Hypersensitivity

Reference: Ananthnarayan and paniker's textbook of Microbiology 12th edition, page number:162

questions.text: A person who met with a road traffic accident recently had undergone grafting using patient's own tissue as shown in the image. Identify the graft from the following list?
questions.solution:
Topic: Immunology

SubTopic: Transplantation immunology

Grafts are classified on basis of who is donor


Reference: Ananthnarayan and paniker’s textbook of Microbiology 12th edition, Page 183

questions.text: Which of the following is the enzyme conjugate?
questions.solution:
This is ELISA test. ELISA stands for Enzyme linked immuno sorbent assay.

Principle of ELISA is antigen antibody interaction. Here the specific antibodies associate or bind to its target antigen. Only when the interaction takes place the substrate can bind to the enzyme. There by substrate conversion can be observed. Hence positive result Is obtained.

There are many types of ELISA.

  • Sandwithch ELISA,
  • Direct ELISA
  • Indirect ELISA
  • Competitive ELISA

In given Image B is enzyme conjugate.

Topic: Immunology

SubTopic: Ag Ab reaction

Reference: Ananthnarayan and paniker's textbook of Microbiology 12th edition,page number :105

questions.text:
A HIV positive patient with CD4 count <50 develops Diarrhea. Stool sample collected from the patient demonstrates acid fast organisms?
Which is the most likely agent
questions.solution:
Topic: Virology

SubTopic: Opportunistic infection in AIDS

HIV is immunocompromised condition, patient develops diarrhea in HIV. Common parasitic form which causes diarrhae is C parvum and related parasite. These are acid fast in nature. Modified Acid fast stain is used for staining of these. 1% H2So4 is used for staining purpose. So they are less acid fast than M tuberculosis.

Other opportunistic infections are – Toxoplasma, isospora, Cryptospora

Reference: Ananthnarayan and paniker’s textbook of Microbiology 12th edition, page number:67

questions.text: Which of the following need not be screened before transfusion?
questions.solution:
Topic: General microbiology

SubTopic: Blood transfusion

Blood transfusion is most common transplant of tissue.

We have to match only blood groups of patients.

Any healthy person can donate the blood.

But there are certain disease which can be transmitted through blood transfusion like HIV, Syphilis, Malaria, Hepatitis B ,Hepatitits C

Dengue is not transmitted through blood transfusion.

Reference: Review of Microbiology and immunology, Apurva shashtry 9thedition Page number 333

questions.text: Microbiological test for diagnosing Leptospira infection is?
questions.solution:
Topic: Bacteriology

SubTopic: Leptospirosis

Leptospira is associated with 3 R

Rat

Rice field

Rain

Leptospirosis is most wide spread zoonoses.

_High risk group

Farmer, sewage worker, worker in fishing industry, veterinarians.

_Lab diagnosis

Increase ESR

Leukocytosis

Mild thrombocytopenia

Increase serum bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase.

Increased prothrombin time

BUN and creatinine may be raised.

_Isolation of organism done on following media

EMJH medium

Fletcher medium

Korthof medium

Stuart medium

_Serological test

Microscopic agglutination test

ELISA

Indirect hemagglutination test

Macroscopic slide agglutinatin test

Reference: Review of Microbiology and immunology, Apurva shashtry 9thedition Page number 450.

questions.text: An HIV positive patient with a CD4 count of 300/cumm presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown in the figure. On microscopy budding yeasts and pseudo-hyphae are seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Topic: Virology

SubTopic: Opportunistic infection in AIDS

Given is case of opportunistic infection in AIDS. As HIv virus infection progress patients CD4 cell count strarts decreasing.

And patient starts having opportunistic infections.

In given case, CD4 cell count is 300/cumm and pt has mucosal lesions in mouth, from microscopy finding it is candida infection.

Reference: Review of Microbiology and immunology, Apurva shashtry 9thedition Page number 612.

questions.text: IN NICU of a pediatric hospital there was outbreak of. All child were having blood culture positive For staphylococcus aureus positive organism. To confirm the outbreak microbiologist wanted to do phage typing. for phage typing, how many phages of staphylococcus aureus are used
questions.solution:
Topic: Bacteriology

SubTopic: Phage typing

Bacteriophage typing of staphylococci is based on susceptibility of cocci to bacteriophages. This is carried out by pattern method where a set of 23 standard typing phages of S aureus are used to type staphylococcal isolates and distinguish them from one another by their pattern of susceptibility to lysis.

Incorrect Option A: 11 number was given to distract the student

Incorrect Option B: 16 number was given to distract the student

Incorrect Option D: 20 number was given to distract the student

Reference: Essential of clinical microbiology 3rd edition, Page number: 786

questions.text: A pt. presented with multiple episodes of bloody diarrhoea. On investigations of blood sample Enterohemorrhagic strain of E. coli was isolated. On which of the following media this organism can be cultured?
questions.solution:
E coli causes diarrhea. There are many species, Enteropathogenic, Entero invasive, Enterohemoorhagic etc

Enterohemorrhagic E coli causes symptoms just like shigella bacteria causing dysentery. Patient will present with blood and pus in stool.

For growth of Enterohemorrahgic E coli, sorbitol macConkey agar is used. As selective media.

Topic: Bacteriology

SubTopic: Diarrhea

Reference: Ananthnarayan and paniker's textbook of Microbiology 12th edition, page number:95

questions.text: A patient. is taking Clindamycin for a long period of time presented with diarrhea. Which of the following is causative organism for this?
questions.solution:
This is a case of antibiotic associated diarrhea. Most common organsm which cause this is Cl difficile.

It is acquired from hospital most of time.

Risk factors

  • Clindamycin
  • Ampicillin
  • Cephalosporin
  • Piperacillintazobactum

Other risk factors are

  • Old age, greater severity of underlying illness
  • Gastrointestinal surgery
  • Used electric thermometer
  • Central tube feeding
  • Antacid use
  • Proton pump inhibitor

Topic: Bacteriology

SubTopic: Antibiotic associated diarrhea

Reference: Harrison Principle of internal medicine, 19th edition, page number:1091

choices.text: Globally the most common species among them to cause diarrhea is C. parvum
Oocyst is infective immediately after coming out in stool
They do not have the property of internal autoinfection

questions.text: Immunocompromised patient after renal transplantation c/o chronic diarrhoea. On staining the stool by Kinyoun stain, 4-6 microns. Which is true?
questions.solution:
Topic: Immunology

SubTopic: Opportunistic infection after transplant

This is opportunistic organism causing diarrhea in immuno compromised case. And the structure in stool is acid fast.

Cryptospora, cyclospora, iso spora species can cause this.

They can be differentiated by size of oocyst. All are eqully acid fast, 1 % H2so4 is required for doing modified znstaining.

Globally the most common species among them to cause diarrhea is not C parvum.

They are not obligate intracellular.

They have property of internal auto infection.

Occyst coming out in stool are infective immediately. So option B is correct.

Reference: Ananthnarayan and paniker, Textbook of parasitology 11th edition, page number 200.

questions.text: Child with bloody diarrhoea followed by joint pains 2 weeks later. Likely cause-
questions.solution:
Topic: Bacteriology

SubTopic: Dysentery

This is a case of dysenetery,which is caused by shigella species.

Shigella species are classified on basis of mannitol fermentation.

Mannitol fermenting – Sh flexneri, sh boydii, sh sonnei

Mannitol non fermenting – sh dysenteriae

Complicaiton are most oftern seen In infection with Sh dysenteriae type I and include arthritis, toxic neuritis, conjunctivitis, parotitis and in children intussuception.

HUS ( hemolytic uremic syndrome) may occur in severe cases.

Sever dysentery most likely involves infection due to S dysenteriae type I, occurs less commonly with S flexneri and is least likely with S sonnei or S boydii.

XLD medium is used as selective media for growth of Shigella.

Shigella toxin inhibits protein synthesis by inactivating 60 S ribosome.

Reference: Ananthnarayan and paniker’s textbook of Microbiology 12th edition, page number:286

questions.text: Flask shaped ulcers in the intestine are caused by
questions.solution:
Topic: Parasitology

SubTopic: E histolytica

E histolytica is common pathogen for human.

Cyst and trophozoite are two forms of parasite.

All pathogenicity is due to tropozoite.

It produces flask shaped ulcer in intestine. Rarely this ulcer ruptures and produces intestinal perforation.

Apart from intestinal amoebiasis, extra intestinal amoebiasis is also common.

Reference: Parasitology by Chatterjee 12th edition, page number 15.

questions.text: A patient presents with GI distress, on enquiry patient informed he usually eats food outside. Which of the following hepatitis can develop following this event.
questions.solution:
Hepatitis A is food borne illness, occurs due to consumption of contaminated water or food. Hepatitis B and C are blood borne illness. Hepatitis B, C and D spreads through sexual route, blood transfusion, sharing needles etc. Incubation period of Hepatitis A is 15-45 days, Hepatitis B 30-180 days, HCV 15 t o160 days, HDV 30-180 days, HEV 14-60 days. HEV is also Food borne illness. It also spread through feco oral route.

Topic: Virology

SubTopic: Hepatitis A

Reference: Ananthnarayan and paniker's textbook of Microbiology 12th edition, Page number:540

questions.text: Hepatitis B subunit vaccine is derived from which antigen
questions.solution:
Topic: Virology

SubTopic: Hepatitis B

HBV contains two different antigenic components

  • Common group reactive antigen a
  • Two pairs of type specific antigen d-y and w-r oly one member of each pair being present at a time.

HBV can be divided into four major antigenic types.

  • Adw
  • Adr
  • Ayw
  • Ayr

For vaccine production HBsAg antigen is used. It starts antibody production after vaccine as this antigen is highly immunogenic.

Reference: Ananthnarayan and paniker’s textbook of Microbiology 12th edition Page number: 640

questions.text: Shown in the figure is the HBV card test. Which of the following is the principle of this test?
questions.solution:
Topic: Virology

SubTopic: Hepatitis B

Hepatitis B can be diagnosed by many ways, rapid card test, principle is chromatography test.

ELISA is one of method to diagnose hepatitis B infection.

PCR is also used for diagnosis of Hepatitis B infection.

Rapid chromatography is easy and cost effective, it has good sensitivity and specificity.

Reference: Ananthnarayan and paniker’s textbook of Microbiology 12th edition, page number: 445

questions.text: E antigen(HBeAg) of Hepatitis B virus is a product of which gene
questions.solution:
Topic: Virology

SubTopic: Hepatitis B

E antigen ( HBeAg ) of Hepatitis B virus is product of Gene C

Other options are given to distract.

Reference: Ananthnarayan and paniker’s textbook of Microbiology 12th edition, page number 599

questions.text: Presence of HBeAg in patients with hepatitis indicates
questions.solution:
Hepatitis B virus infection incubation period varies from 30 days to 180 days.

Various antigen and antibodies are detected to see whether it is acute inf or chronic inf.

HBsag Antigen if positive for 6 months - it is called carrier stage

HBeag if present it suggest high infectivity

There is no term as simple carrier.

Topic: Virology

SubTopic: Carrier of Hepatitis B

Reference: Ananthnarayan and paniker's textbook of Microbiology 12th edition, page number 955
